questions.question: What is a key aspect of reliability and redundancy in an aircraft electrical system?

options.a: The system must ensure continuous operation, even in case of failure.
options.b: The system must only have a single power source.
options.c: The system should prioritize non-essential loads during failures.

questions.explanation: The system must ensure continuous operation, even in case of failure. [cite: 51]

questions.question: What is 'load shedding capability' in aircraft electrical systems?

options.a: The ability to increase power to all systems during a power generation failure.
options.b: The system's ability to automatically disconnect or turn off non-essential electrical loads to preserve power for essential systems during failures.
options.c: The manual increase of electrical loads during an overload condition.

questions.explanation: Load shedding capability in aircraft electrical systems refers to the system's ability to automatically disconnect or turn off non-essential electrical loads in order to preserve power for essential and critical systems during a power generation failure, an overload condition, or operation on limited power sources. [cite: 57, 58, 59]

questions.question: Which of the following are examples of independent and multiple power sources in aircraft?

options.b: Engine-driven generators, Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) generator, and Battery.

questions.explanation: Aircraft must have independent and multiple power sources, such as engine-driven generators (primary power), Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) generator (ground/backup power), and Battery (emergency power). [cite: 81, 82]

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) in an aircraft?

options.a: To provide mechanical power for flight control surfaces.
options.b: To provide electrical power and pneumatic air when the main engines are off.
options.c: To convert AC power to DC power for onboard systems.

questions.explanation: The APU provides electrical power and pneumatic air when the main engines are off. [cite: 97]

questions.question: What is a Ground Power Unit (GPU) primarily used for?

options.a: To start the main engines during flight.
options.b: To supply electrical power while the aircraft is parked, to avoid using fuel-consuming systems like the APU.
options.c: To provide backup electrical power in flight if certified.

questions.explanation: The GPU is an external electrical power supply used to power the aircraft from the ground, usually supplied by airport ground equipment, primarily to save fuel by avoiding APU use on the ground. [cite: 113, 115, 123]

questions.question: What are typical AC voltage and frequency standards in aircraft electrical systems?

options.b: 115V AC 1-phase, 200V 3-phase, 400 Hz

questions.explanation: Typical aircraft electrical system specifications for AC voltage are 115V 1-phase and 200V 3-phase, with an AC frequency of 400 Hz. [cite: 137]

questions.question: Which of the following are considered critical systems that must always have power available?

options.b: Flight instruments (EFIS), navigation & communication, and fire protection.

questions.explanation: Power must always be available for critical systems such as flight instruments (EFIS), navigation & communication, fuel pumps, fire protection, and emergency lighting. [cite: 142, 143, 144, 145, 146]

questions.question: What do aircraft electrical systems protect against?

options.b: Overload, short circuits, and overvoltage/undervoltage.

questions.explanation: Systems must protect against overload, short circuits, and overvoltage/undervoltage. [cite: 155, 156, 157]

questions.question: What is the purpose of load management in aircraft electrical systems?

options.a: To power all systems equally at all times.
options.b: To prioritize critical systems and allow for automatic or manual load shedding during failures.
options.c: To only power non-essential loads during normal operation.

questions.explanation: Load prioritization ensures critical systems are powered first, and automatic or manual load shedding occurs during generator failure or overload. [cite: 163, 164]

questions.question: What is EMI (Electromagnetic Interference)?

options.a: A type of electrical power source.
options.b: Any unwanted electromagnetic energy that disrupts or degrades the performance of electronic systems.
options.c: A system for managing electrical loads.

questions.explanation: EMI is any unwanted electromagnetic energy that disrupts or degrades the performance of electronic systems. [cite: 201]

questions.question: What does EMC (Electromagnetic Compatibility) ensure in aircraft?

options.a: That all electronic systems emit maximum EMI.
options.b: That all electronic systems and components do not emit EMI above allowable limits and can operate correctly in the presence of EMI from other sources.
options.c: That systems interfere with each other for redundancy.

questions.explanation: EMC means that all electronic systems and components do not emit EMI above allowable limits and can operate correctly in the presence of EMI from other sources. It ensures that all systems coexist without interfering with each other. [cite: 224, 225, 226]

questions.question: What are 'Line Replaceable Units (LRUs)' in aircraft systems?

options.a: Components that require in-depth repair on the aircraft.
options.b: Modular, self-contained units designed for quick removal and replacement during maintenance.
options.c: Fixed components that are never replaced.

questions.explanation: Aircraft systems are increasingly built with Line Replaceable Units (LRUs), which are modular, self-contained units designed for quick removal and replacement during maintenance. [cite: 276, 277, 278]

questions.question: Under what environmental conditions must aircraft electrical systems operate?

options.b: Only at sea level and low humidity.
options.c: Vibration, temperature extremes , and moisture/altitude variations.

questions.explanation: Aircraft electrical systems must operate under vibration, temperature extremes

questions.question: Which international aviation standards must aircraft electrical systems comply with?

options.b: CS-25 (EASA) or FAR Part 25 (FAA) for transport aircraft, and DO-160 for environmental conditions.

questions.explanation: The system must comply with international aviation standards, including CS-25 (EASA) or FAR Part 25 (FAA) for transport aircraft, and DO-160 for environmental conditions. [cite: 350, 351]

questions.question: What are the two main groups of electricity power sources on an aircraft?

options.b: Batteries and Generators.

questions.explanation: Electricity power sources on an aircraft may be classified into two groups: Batteries and Generators. [cite: 551, 556]

questions.question: What is the difference between continuous and intermittent electrical loads in an aircraft?

options.a: Continuous loads are only powered on the ground, while intermittent loads are powered during flight.
options.b: Continuous loads are always powered during flight (e.g., flight instruments), while intermittent loads are operated only when needed (e.g., landing gear, flaps).
options.c: Continuous loads are for passenger services, and intermittent loads are for emergency systems.

questions.explanation: Continuous loads are always powered during flight (e.g., flight instruments, avionics, fuel pumps), while intermittent loads are operated only when needed (e.g., landing gear, flaps, cabin lights). [cite: 612, 613, 615]

questions.question: What are 'busbars' in an aircraft electrical system?

options.a: Devices that convert AC to DC power.
options.b: Conductors that act as distribution centers for electric power.
options.c: Switches used to control high-current loads.

questions.explanation: Busbars are conductors that act as distribution centers for electric power, where output from generators is sent before distribution throughout the system. [cite: 650, 651]

questions.question: What is the function of a 'Generator Control Unit (GCU)'?

options.b: To act as a voltage regulator, direct current to the battery for recharging, and provide circuit and generator protection.

questions.explanation: The main functions of a Generator Control Unit (GCU) are to act as a voltage regulator, direct current to the battery for recharging, and provide circuit and generator protection by disconnecting the generator from the system when electrical abnormalities occur. [cite: 728, 729, 730]

questions.question: Which of the following are examples of control devices in aircraft electrical systems?

options.b: Switches, Rheostats, Relays, and Solenoids.

questions.explanation: Control devices include Switches, Rheostats, Relays, and Solenoids. [cite: 758, 759, 760, 761]

questions.question: What is the primary function of relays in an aircraft electrical system?

options.a: To control the amount of current flow as dimmer devices.
options.b: To move a shaft over a short distance for mechanical control.
options.c: Electromagnetic switching devices which are used to remotely control electric circuits carrying large amounts of current.

questions.explanation: Relays are electromagnetic switching devices which are used to remotely control electric circuits carrying large amounts of current. [cite: 870]

questions.question: What is the purpose of voltmeters and ammeters in an aircraft electrical system?

options.b: To show voltage and current levels.
options.c: To convert AC to DC power.

questions.explanation: Voltmeters and Ammeters show voltage and current levels. [cite: 963]

questions.question: What is a primary use of batteries in aircraft during preflight?

options.a: To power all flight systems continuously.
options.b: To start the APU and/or the engines.
options.c: To provide power for the galley equipment only.

questions.explanation: Batteries are used during preflight to start the APU and/or the engines. [cite: 1052, 1053]

questions.question: In the event of a main power failure, how are batteries typically used in aircraft?

options.a: They are disconnected to prevent further issues.
options.b: They are used as an emergency source for essential use.
options.c: They are only used for non-critical systems.

questions.explanation: In the event of the failure, battery used as an emergency source for essential use. [cite: 1060, 1061]

questions.question: Why do some fixed aircraft equipment, such as ELTs and CVRs, have their own dedicated batteries?

options.a: To reduce the load on the main aircraft electrical system during normal operation.
options.b: To ensure uninterrupted power, especially during emergencies or when the main power supply is unavailable.
options.c: To provide additional power for passenger entertainment systems.

questions.explanation: Certain critical or independent systems come with dedicated batteries to ensure uninterrupted power, especially during emergencies or when the main power supply is unavailable. [cite: 1067, 1079, 1080, 1081, 1082, 1083]

questions.question: What are 'intermittent loads' in an aircraft electrical system?

options.a: Electrical devices that run constantly during flight.
options.b: Electrical devices that are used occasionally or for short durations.
options.c: Loads that are only powered by the alternator.

questions.explanation: Intermittent loads are electrical devices that are used occasionally or for short durations. [cite: 1099]

questions.question: How does an aircraft electrical system handle intermittent loads that may briefly exceed alternator output?

options.a: By increasing the alternator's output indefinitely.
options.b: Through battery supplementation, load shedding, and Power Management Units (PMUs).
options.c: By completely shutting down non-essential systems.

questions.explanation: The system handles overload through battery supplementation (the battery supports the alternator during short overloads), load shedding (non-essential systems are turned off), and Power Management Units (PMUs) which prioritize critical systems and manage loads intelligently. [cite: 1126, 1127, 1128, 1129, 1130]

questions.question: What is the basic definition of a battery?

options.a: A device that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.
options.b: A device that converts chemical energy directly into electrical energy.
options.c: A device that stores kinetic energy.

questions.explanation: A battery is a device that converts chemical energy directly into electrical energy. [cite: 1157, 1274]

questions.question: What is the basic building block of a battery?

options.b: Electrode

questions.explanation: A cell is the basic building block of the battery. [cite: 1183]

questions.question: What is the function of 'separators' in a battery cell?

options.a: To allow chemical reactions to mix freely.
options.b: To keep the plates separated and thus prevent an internal short circuit.
options.c: To convert chemical energy to electrical energy.

questions.explanation: Separators keep the plates separated and thus prevent an internal short circuit. [cite: 1218, 1219]

questions.question: What is 'electrolyte' in a battery?

options.a: A solid material that conducts electricity.
options.b: A liquid (or gaseous) chemical that enters into or aids a chemical action between other elements, providing for the movement of ions.
options.c: A protective outer casing of the battery.

questions.explanation: Electrolyte is a liquid (or gaseous) chemical that enters into or aids a chemical action between other elements, and is a conductive medium that provides for the movement of ions (current flow) between the positive and negative plates of a cell. [cite: 1228, 1229]

questions.question: What are the two main classifications of batteries?

options.b: Primary and Secondary.

questions.explanation: Batteries are classified into Primary and Secondary types. [cite: 1173, 1178]

questions.question: What is the key characteristic of a 'Primary Battery'?

options.a: The electrochemical reaction is reversible, allowing for recharging.
options.b: The electrochemical reaction is not reversible, meaning they are often referred to as dry cells and cannot be recharged.
options.c: They are only used for emergency situations.

questions.explanation: In primary batteries, the electrochemical reaction is not reversible. Since there's no liquid in them, they're often referred to as dry cells. [cite: 1247, 1248]

questions.question: What is the key characteristic of 'Secondary Batteries'?

options.b: They are single-use devices.
options.c: The electrochemical reaction is reversible by the application of an electrical power between the electrodes, allowing them to be recharged.

questions.explanation: In secondary batteries, the electrochemical reaction is reversible by the application of an electrical power between the electrodes. [cite: 1256]

questions.question: What are the main applications of batteries in aircraft?

options.b: Mainly for engine starting and a source of emergency power.

questions.explanation: Mainly on an aircraft, it is used for engine starting and a source of emergency power. [cite: 1283]

questions.question: Which types of batteries are commonly used in aircraft?

options.b: Lead Acid, Nickel Cadmium (NiCd), and Lithium-ion.

questions.explanation: Common types include Lead Acid, Nickel Cadmium (NiCd), and Lithium-ion. [cite: 1290, 1291, 1297, 1298, 1299]

questions.question: What is a crucial safety precaution when working with aircraft batteries?

options.a: Always leave the charger on when unplugging the battery.
options.b: Always remove metallic jewelry prior to working and wear eye protection.
options.c: Always disregard manufacturer recommendations for maintenance.

questions.explanation: Always remove metallic jewelry prior to working and always wear eye protection. [cite: 1305, 1306]

questions.question: What is the electrolyte in a lead-acid battery composed of?

options.b: Distilled water mixed with sulfuric acid.

questions.explanation: The electrolyte is distilled water mixed with sulfuric acid. [cite: 1335, 1337, 1366]

questions.question: What is the approximate voltage of a single cell in a lead-acid battery?
questions.explanation: Each cell has app. 2.2v, but is simply rated as 2v. [cite: 1360]

questions.question: What happens to the electrolyte (sulfuric acid) concentration as a lead-acid battery discharges?

options.b: It remains constant.

questions.explanation: Sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄) concentration decreases and water (H₂O) forms as the battery discharges. [cite: 1380]

questions.question: What substance coats the positive and negative plates of a lead-acid battery during discharge?

options.b: Spongy lead.

questions.explanation: The reaction between sulfuric acid and the lead plates begins to coat both positive and negative plates with a substance called lead sulfate also known as sulfation. [cite: 1387, 1388, 1393]

questions.question: What happens if a lead-acid battery is discharged below 10.5 volts?

options.b: It will severely damage the battery.
options.c: It will initiate a rapid self-recharge.

questions.explanation: NOTE: Discharging a lead acid battery below 10.5 volts will severely damage it! [cite: 1395]

questions.question: When disconnecting a lead-acid battery from an aircraft, which lead should be disconnected first?

options.b: Negative lead.

questions.explanation: When disconnecting the battery from an aircraft, disconnect the negative lead first, when installing, always connect the negative lead last. [cite: 1398]

questions.question: What does 'battery capacity' measure?

options.a: The maximum voltage the battery can produce.
options.b: The measure of battery’s total available current, equal to the time required to fully discharge the battery multiplied by the current drawn.
options.c: The internal resistance of the battery.

questions.explanation: Battery capacity is equal to a time required to fully discharge battery multiplied by the current drawn from the battery. This means it is the measure of battery’s total available current. [cite: 1407, 1408]

questions.question: How is the capacity of a lead-acid battery typically measured?

options.a: By measuring the terminal voltage at rest.
options.b: By discharging it over a consistent time, typically a 5-hour discharge rate.
options.c: By adding more sulfuric acid to the electrolyte.

questions.explanation: To determine the exact capacity of a battery, all aircraft batteries must be discharged over consistent time in 5hrs discharge rate. [cite: 1409]

questions.question: What does a hydrometer measure in a lead-acid battery to determine its state of charge?

options.b: Specific gravity (density) of the electrolyte.

questions.explanation: It is typical to use Hydrometer to measure the state of charge. Hydrometer measures specific gravity (density) of a liquid. [cite: 1413]

questions.question: Does adding active ingredients (like sulfuric acid) to the electrolyte recharge a lead-acid battery?

options.a: Yes, it fully recharges the battery.
options.b: No, it only increases the specific gravity and does not recharge the battery; a charging current must be passed through it.

questions.explanation: Adding the active ingredient (such as sulfuric acid in a lead-acid battery) to the electrolyte does not recharge the battery—it only increases the specific gravity of the electrolyte. A charging current must be passed through the battery to recharge it. [cite: 1419, 1420, 1422, 1423]

questions.question: During periodic inspection on aircraft, what aspects of the battery should be inspected?

options.a: Only the physical condition of the battery case.
options.b: Cables for insulation condition, chafing, and security of connections; battery mounting; terminal connections; and the ventilation system.

questions.explanation: During this inspection, the battery should be inspected for cables for condition of insulation, chafing, and security of connections, its mounting, inspecting the terminal connections and inspecting the ventilation system of the aircraft and battery box. [cite: 1397]

questions.question: Are Nickel Cadmium (NiCd) batteries resilient to both overcharge and undercharge?

options.a: No, they are very sensitive to both.
options.b: Yes, they are resilient to both overcharge and undercharge.

questions.explanation: Nickel cadmium cells are resilient to both overcharge and undercharge. [cite: 1443]

questions.question: What is the nominal voltage for a single Ni-Cd cell during discharge?

options.b: 1.2 Volts

questions.explanation: The cells are rechargeable and deliver a voltage of 1.2 volt (CCV) during discharging. [cite: 1449, 1450]

questions.question: Why is it impossible to use the specific gravity of the electrolyte to determine the charge state of a Ni-Cd battery?

options.b: The composition of the electrolyte (potassium hydroxide) remains essentially constant at any state of charge, so its specific gravity doesn't change.
options.c: The battery's internal resistance interferes with the measurement.

questions.explanation: The composition of the electrolyte remains a solution of potassium hydroxide because hydroxide ions are added to the electrolyte as quickly as they are removed. For this reason the specific gravity of the electrolyte remains essentially constant at any state of charge. Therefore, it is impossible to use the specific gravity as an indication of the charge state of the battery. [cite: 1470, 1471, 1473, 1475]

questions.question: How can the state of charge in Ni-Cd batteries be measured?

options.b: Through terminal voltage (especially under load), temperature monitoring, and charge/discharge tracking (ampere-hours in and out).

questions.explanation: The state of charge can be measured through terminal voltage (rough estimate, best under load), temperature monitoring (overcharging causes temperature rise), and charge/discharge tracking (log ampere-hours in and out). [cite: 1477, 1478, 1479]

questions.question: What is a key difference in construction between Ni-Cd batteries and lead-acid batteries?

options.a: Ni-Cd batteries are typically sealed units, while lead-acid batteries have replaceable individual cells.
options.b: Ni-Cd batteries have replaceable individual cells, unlike lead-acid batteries which are typically sealed as a whole unit.
options.c: Ni-Cd batteries do not use separators.

questions.explanation: Nickel-Cadmium (Ni-Cd) batteries feature replaceable individual cells, which makes maintenance and repair easier. In contrast, lead-acid batteries are typically sealed as a whole unit, and replacing a single faulty cell usually isn't practical. [cite: 1457, 1461, 1462]

questions.question: Which charging method is preferred for Ni-Cd batteries?

options.b: Constant current charging (CCC).

questions.explanation: The CCC method is the preferred method for charging Ni-Cd batteries. [cite: 166]

questions.question: What is an advantage of Nickel Cadmium batteries over Lead Acid batteries?

options.a: They are far less expensive to buy.
options.b: They have a longer life and their terminal voltage remains almost constant during the discharge cycle.
options.c: They are more susceptible to thermal runaway.

questions.explanation: They have a longer life and the terminal voltage remains almost constant during the discharge cycle. [cite: 1498]

questions.question: What is a disadvantage of Nickel Cadmium batteries compared to Lead Acid batteries?

options.a: They are less susceptible to thermal runaway.
options.b: They are far more expensive to buy and maintain.
options.c: Each cell has a higher voltage, requiring fewer cells.

questions.explanation: They are far more expensive to buy and maintain. [cite: 1499]

questions.question: Can Ni-Cd batteries be stored for long periods in both charged and uncharged conditions?

options.a: No, only in a charged condition.
options.b: Yes, unlike lead-acid, Ni-Cd can be stored for long periods in charged/uncharged condition.
options.c: Only if fully discharged and shorted.

questions.explanation: Unlike lead-acid, nicad stored for long period of time in charged/uncharged condition. [cite: 1702, 1703]

questions.question: What are some advantages of Lithium-ion batteries in aircraft?

options.a: They are heavy and have frequent gassing.
options.b: They have a higher cranking voltage and amps, no gassing or corrosion, less toxicity, and a longer life span.
options.c: They require high maintenance and have a short life.

questions.explanation: Lithium batteries have age of higher cranking voltage & amps, no gassing or corrosion, and less toxicity. They are cleaner and environmentally friendly, have advanced and very safe energy storage, are 1/4th or less the weight of a lead battery, and have a longer life span—thus cheaper than SLA over time. [cite: 1510, 1511, 1512]

questions.question: What are the materials typically used for the electrolyte, cathode, and anode in Lithium-ion cells?

options.a: Sulfuric acid, lead dioxide, and lead.
options.b: Lithium-ion electrolyte, cobalt cathode, and graphite anode.
options.c: Potassium hydroxide, nickel compounds, and cadmium compounds.

questions.explanation: The materials used in these cells are: electrolyte: lithium-ion, cathode: cobalt, anode: graphite. [cite: 1513]

questions.question: What is a significant disadvantage of Lithium-ion batteries?

options.b: Low flammability.
options.c: Higher product cost and they are extremely flammable.

questions.explanation: Disadvantages include higher product cost and being extremely flammable. [cite: 1516]

questions.question: What is the nominal cell voltage and charging voltage for a Lithium-ion battery?

options.b: 2.2 V nominal, 2.4 V charging.

questions.explanation: The nominal cell voltage is 3.6 V, and the charging voltage is 4.2 V with associated current limiting. [cite: 1529]

questions.question: What is a drawback of simple DC generators?

options.b: They produce pulsating DC, causing hamming.

questions.explanation: The drawback is pulsating DC, which causes hamming.

questions.question: What are the main parts of a DC generator?

options.b: Field Assembly, armature assembly, commutator, and brush.

questions.explanation: Field Assembly, armature assembly, commutator and brush are the main parts of DC generator. [cite: 1560]

questions.question: What type of armature winding is used for low voltage and high current applications?

options.b: Lap winding.

questions.explanation: Lap winding is for low voltage and high current. [cite: 1553]

questions.question: What type of armature winding is used for high voltage and low current applications?

options.b: Wave winding.

questions.explanation: Wave winding is for high voltage and low current. [cite: 1554]

questions.question: What are the possible losses in a DC generator?

options.b: Copper losses, iron losses, and mechanical losses.

questions.explanation: Copper losses, iron losses and mechanical losses are the total losses in DC generator. [cite: 1560]

questions.question: Strictly speaking, why is 'DC alternator' considered a misnomer?

options.a: Because alternators always produce DC directly.
options.b: Because an alternator produces alternating current (AC), while a DC generator produces direct current (DC).
options.c: Because it only produces mechanical energy.

questions.explanation: Strictly speaking, 'DC alternator' is a misnomer because an alternator produces alternating current (AC), while a DC generator produces direct current (DC). [cite: 1566, 1567]

questions.question: In a DC-output alternator (AC alternator with rectifier), where are the armature windings located?

options.b: On the stator (stationary) — this is where AC is generated.
options.c: They are not present in a DC-output alternator.

questions.explanation: In a DC-output Alternator (AC alternator with rectifier), the armature windings are on the stator (stationary) — this is where AC is generated. [cite: 1577]

questions.question: What is the function of brushes in a DC-output alternator?

options.a: They collect output power from the armature.
options.b: They supply excitation current to the rotor's field windings via slip rings, not for collecting output power.

questions.explanation: Small brushes supply current to the rotor's field windings via slip rings — these are low-current brushes, not for collecting power. Brushes are on the field (rotor) — not for picking up voltage, but to supply excitation current to create a magnetic field. [cite: 1579, 1580, 1581]

questions.subtopic: Key Differences (DC Generator vs DC Alternator)
questions.question: In a DC Generator, where is DC current collected?

options.b: Via a commutator and brushes on the rotor.

questions.explanation: In a DC Generator, DC is collected via commutator and brushes on the rotor. [cite: 1589]

questions.question: What is a feature of a static inverter?

options.a: High maintenance and long warmup period.
options.b: Low efficiency and noisy operation.
options.c: High efficiency, low maintenance, and no warmup period required.

questions.explanation: Features of static Inverter include high efficiency, low maintenance, long life, no warmup period required, capability of starting under load, and extremely quiet operation. [cite: 1598, 1599, 1600]

questions.question: Why is stranded wire generally preferred over solid wire in aircraft?

options.b: It is generally more flexible and less susceptible to fatigue due to vibration.

questions.explanation: Stranded wire is generally more flexible than solid wire, making is easier to handle. Stranded wire is also less susceptible to fatigue due to vibration. [cite: 1604, 1605]

questions.question: What does the term 'cable' include in aircraft electrical installations?

options.b: Two or more insulated conductors in a common covering, shielded cables, twisted pairs, and coaxial cables.

questions.explanation: The term 'cable' includes two or more insulated conductors in a common covering, shielded cables, twisted pairs, and coaxial cables. [cite: 1606, 1607, 1608]

questions.question: How does the American Wire Gauge (AWG) number relate to wire diameter?

options.a: Higher AWG number means thicker wire.
options.b: Higher AWG number means thinner wire.
options.c: AWG number has no relation to wire diameter.

questions.explanation: The wire diameter becomes smaller as the gage numbers become larger. The higher the AWG number, the thinner the wire. [cite: 1614, 1615]

questions.question: What are the two types of markings for aircraft electrical cables?

options.b: Direct marking and Indirect marking.

questions.explanation: There are two markings: Direct marking and Indirect marking. [cite: 1622]

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'unit number' in aircraft wire coding?

options.b: To distinguish between wires of two or more identical pieces of equipment installed in the same aircraft.

questions.explanation: The unit number is used to distinguish between wires of two or more identical pieces of equipment installed in the same aircraft. [cite: 1629]

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'bonding' in aircraft electrical systems?

options.b: To create very low resistance by connecting various metallic parts, reducing interference, lightning damage, static charge buildup, fire hazard, and electric shock.

questions.explanation: Bonding involves connecting various metallic parts to create very low resistance, which reduces interference, lightning damage, prevents buildup of static charge, reduces fire hazard, and prevents electric shock. [cite: 1647]

questions.question: What are the advantages of the crimped method for securing terminals to conductors?

options.a: It is slow and causes voltage drops.
options.b: Fabrication is faster and easier, good electrical conductivity, stronger connections, and elimination of solder-related problems.
options.c: It is prone to dry joints.

questions.explanation: Advantages of crimped method include: Fabrication is faster and easier, and uniform operation is assured; Good electrical conductivity and a lower voltage drop is assured; Connections are stronger; Shorting due to solder slop and messy flux problem are eliminated; and 'Wicking' of solder on conductor wires and 'dry' joints are eliminated. [cite: 1653]

questions.question: Which of the following is a common connector style in aircraft?

options.b: Circular connector style.

questions.explanation: Common connector types include Circular connector style, Bayonet Coupling Circular Connectors, and Screw Thread Coupling Connectors. [cite: 1660]

questions.question: What are common circuit protection devices in aircraft?

options.b: Circuit breakers, fuses, current limiters, switches, relays, and solenoids.

questions.explanation: Possible circuit protection devices are: Circuit breaker, Fuse, Current limiter, Switch, Relay, Solenoid. [cite: 1666]

questions.question: What is the recommendation for resetting circuit breakers in aircraft?

options.a: It is always recommended to reset them immediately.
options.b: Resetting circuit breakers is not recommended in aircraft unless the aircraft is on the ground.

questions.explanation: Reset circuit breaker is not recommended in aircraft. It is re-setted when aircraft is on ground. [cite: 1668]

questions.question: What are the two types of fuses mentioned in the context of aircraft electrical systems?

options.b: Fast acting and Slow blow.

questions.explanation: Two types: Fast acting - open very quickly; Slow blow – Open only on a continued overload. [cite: 1669]

questions.question: What is the purpose of a master switch in an aircraft electrical system?

options.a: To control only the landing lights.
options.b: To disconnect all power sources from the distribution system.
options.c: To activate only the emergency systems.

questions.explanation: A master switch must be provided that will make it possible to disconnect all power sources from the distribution system. [cite: 1678]

questions.question: What does a 'wire bundle' consist of in an aircraft?

options.b: A quantity of wires fastened or secured together and all traveling in the same direction, typically two or more wire groups tied together.

questions.explanation: A wire bundle consists of a quantity of wires fastened or secured together and all traveling in the same direction. A wire bundle consists of two or more wire groups tied together. [cite: 1682, 1685]

questions.question: What is the minimum radius of bends in wire groups or bundles?

options.a: Less than 5 times the outside diameter of the largest wire.
options.b: Not less than 10 times the outside diameter of the largest wire or cable.
options.c: Any radius is acceptable as long as it's not sharp.

questions.explanation: The minimum radius of bends in wire groups or bundles must not be less than 10 times the outside diameter of the largest wire or cable. [cite: 1699]

questions.question: What are the purposes of grounding the aircraft?

options.a: Only to provide static discharge paths.
options.b: To protect aircraft and personnel against hazards from lightning discharge, provide current return paths, protect personnel from shock hazard, and prevent accumulation of static charge.

questions.explanation: Grounding of the aircraft is usually done to protect aircraft and personnel against hazards from lightning discharge, provide current return paths, protect personnel from shock hazard, and prevent accumulation of static charge. [cite: 1710, 1711]

questions.question: What does EWIS (Electrical Wiring Interconnection System) refer to?

options.b: Any wire, wiring device, or combination of these, including termination devices, installed in any area of the airplane for the purpose of transmitting electrical energy between two or more intended termination points.
options.c: Only the hydraulic and pneumatic systems.

questions.explanation: EWIS is any wire, wiring device, or combination of these, including termination devices, installed in any area of the airplane for the purpose of transmitting electrical energy between two or more intended termination points. [cite: 1716]

questions.question: What are common causes of EWIS degradation?

options.b: Vibration, moisture, chemical contamination, and heat.

questions.explanation: Causes of EWIS Degradations include Vibration, Moisture, Chemical contamination, and Heat. [cite: 1723]

questions.question: What is a recommended action before performing maintenance on the aircraft's electrical system?

options.b: Attach a grounding wire to the aircraft and de-energize the electrical system.

questions.explanation: Before performing maintenance on the aircraft, attach a grounding wire to the aircraft and de-energize the electrical system. [cite: 1724]

questions.question: What is the recommended general sequence for cleaning in relation to EWIS maintenance?

options.a: Clean the area first, then identify the contamination source.
options.b: Identify the contamination source, stop or contain it, clean the area, check the environment and drain holes, and ensure no foreign objects are left.

questions.explanation: The general sequence for cleaning includes: Identify the contamination source, Stop or contain the source of contamination, Clean the area, After your cleaning operation check the environment, Check the drain holes of the aircraft as necessary, and Check that no tools or other (for) foreign objects are left behind. [cite: 1742, 1743]

questions.question: What are the three main classifications of aircraft lighting systems?

options.b: External, Internal, and Emergency lighting systems.

questions.explanation: Most aircraft lighting system consists of: External and Internal Lighting and an emergency lighting system. [cite: 1751]

questions.question: Which of the following are part of the exterior lighting system?

options.a: Flight deck and passenger cabin lights.
options.b: Navigation lights, anti-collision lights, and landing/taxi lights.

questions.explanation: Exterior lighting system includes the navigation lights, the anti-collision lights, the landing and taxi lights, the wing ice detection lights, the fin logo lights. [cite: 1753]

questions.question: What is the purpose of navigation lights on an aircraft?

options.a: To illuminate the wings for ice inspection.
options.b: To mark the extremities of an aircraft and give position reference.
options.c: To assist in the evacuation of passengers during an emergency.

questions.explanation: Navigation Lights are used to mark the extremities of an aircraft and give position reference. [cite: 1755]

questions.question: What information can you deduce if you see both a Red and Green Navigation Light on another airplane?

options.a: The other airplane is flying away from you.
options.b: The other airplane is coming at you.
options.c: The other airplane is moving from left to right.

questions.explanation: If you see both a Red and Green Light, the other airplane is coming at you. [cite: 1777]

questions.question: What is the primary function of landing lights?

options.b: To help the pilots see the runway during takeoff and landing.
options.c: To signal other aircraft during flight.

questions.explanation: The landing lights help the pilots see the runway during takeoff and landing. [cite: 1781, 1784]

questions.question: What is the purpose of anti-collision lights?

options.a: To illuminate the tail fin for promotional purposes.
options.b: To make the airplane easier to see in the air and on the ground, and to warn that the engines are running or about to be started.
options.c: To provide interior lighting for passengers.

questions.explanation: The anti-collision lights make the airplane easier to see in the air and on the ground. They also warn the presence of an aircraft and identify its position, and warn that the engines are running or are about to be started. [cite: 1786, 1787, 1788]

questions.question: What is a safety precaution related to strobe lights (a type of anti-collision light)?

options.a: It's safe to touch a new flash tube with bare hands immediately after power removal.
options.b: Do not handle the unit for at least 5 minutes after power is removed, and never touch a new flash tube with bare hands.
options.c: Looking directly into high intensity light is harmless.

questions.explanation: Safety precautions for strobe lights include: Do not handle the unit for at least 5 minutes after power is removed. Never touch a new flash tube with bare hands. Damage to the eyes may result from looking directly into high intensity light. [cite: 1790, 1791, 1792]

questions.question: What are wing illumination lights used for?

options.a: To provide light for the cockpit instruments.
options.b: For scanning/ice detection purposes on wings and engines in flight, and to illuminate the immediate area on the ground.

questions.explanation: Wing illumination lights are provided for scanning/ice detection purposes on wings and engines in flight, and used on ground to illuminate immediate area. [cite: 1794, 1795]

questions.question: What is the primary function of logo lights on an aircraft?

options.b: To illuminate the tail fin for promotional purposes and provide additional awareness in busy airspace.

questions.explanation: Logo lights are used to illuminate tail fin for promotional purposes, and are often used for additional awareness in busy airspace. [cite: 1800, 1801]

questions.question: What do emergency escape slide lights illuminate?

options.b: Escape slide areas for entry and service doors, and over wing escape doors.

questions.explanation: Four exterior lights illuminate escape slide areas for forward and aft entry and forward and aft service doors. An additional four lights illuminate over wing escape doors and areas just aft of wing trailing edge. [cite: 1804, 1805]

questions.question: What do dome lights in the flight compartment provide?

options.b: General illumination for the flight deck area.

questions.explanation: Dome lights supply general illumination for the cabin. They are provided for general illumination of the flight deck area. [cite: 1811, 1814]

questions.question: What is the function of master caution/failure lights?

options.b: To inform the flight crew that a system fault annunciator has illuminated on various panels.
options.c: To illuminate the exterior of the aircraft only.

questions.explanation: Master Caution/Failure Lights inform the flight crew that a system fault annunciator has illuminated on the forward overhead, aft overhead or fire control panels. [cite: 1817, 1818]

questions.question: What does a passenger service unit (PSU) typically contain?

options.b: Reading Lighting, Fasten Seat Belt & No Smoking signs, and Attendant Call button.

questions.explanation: The passenger service unit contains Reading Lighting, Fasten Seat Belt & No Smoking signs, and Attendant Call button. [cite: 1826, 1827]

questions.question: When do emergency lights automatically illuminate?

options.b: Only when manually activated by the flight crew.
options.c: Exit signs and egress paths are illuminated when normal lighting system power is lost.

questions.explanation: Emergency lights automatically illuminate exit signs and egress paths when normal lighting system power is lost. [cite: 1829]

questions.question: What are the main components of a complete fire protection system?

options.b: Fire detection/warning system and fire extinguishing system.

questions.explanation: A complete fire protection system has a Fire detection/warning system and a Fire extinguishing system. [cite: 1841]

questions.question: What are the methods of fire extinguishment?

options.b: Cooling the fuel below its ignition point, removing fuel supply, limiting Oxygen/Smothering, and interrupting Combustion/Chemical Reaction.

questions.explanation: Methods of fire extinguishment include Cooling the fuel below its ignition point, Removing Fuel supply, Limiting Oxygen/Smothering, and Interrupting Combustion/Chemical Reaction. [cite: 1843]

questions.question: What is a key requirement for aircraft fire protection systems?

options.a: They should provide false warnings frequently.
options.b: No false warnings under any flight or ground condition, rapid indication and accurate location of fire, and accurate indication that a fire is out.
options.c: They should be difficult to test.

questions.explanation: Requirements include No false warnings under any flight or ground condition, Rapid indication and accurate location of fire, Accurate indication that a fire is out, Indication that a fire has re-ignited, Continuous indication for duration of a fire, Testing the detector system is possible, and Resists damage. [cite: 1846]

questions.question: What are the three common types of fire detector systems?

options.b: Thermal Switch, Thermocouple, and Continuous Loop.

questions.explanation: Three detector system types in common use are Thermal Switch, Thermocouple, and Continuous Loop. [cite: 1847]

questions.question: In what areas of an aircraft would you typically find a carbon monoxide detector?

options.b: Usually used in cabin and cockpit.

questions.explanation: Carbon Monoxide Detectors are usually used in cabin and cockpit. [cite: 1860]

questions.question: What are the two types of smoke detectors commonly used in aircraft?

options.b: Light refraction and Ionization.

questions.explanation: Smoke Detectors are of two types: Light refraction and Ionization. [cite: 1861]

questions.question: Which fire extinguishing agent is best suited for Class A fires?

options.b: Water or water type which lower the fuel below its ignition point.

questions.explanation: Class A fires respond best to water or water type which lower the fuel below it’s ignition point. [cite: 1877]

questions.question: Which fire extinguishing agent is best suited for Class C fires?

options.b: Carbon dioxide (CO2).

questions.explanation: Class C fires respond best to CO2 which displaces the oxygen. [cite: 1880]

questions.question: What is a characteristic of Halon as a fire extinguishing agent?

options.a: It has high toxicity and conducts electricity.
options.b: It is ozone depleted, a clean agent, electrically non-conducting, and has relatively low toxicity.
options.c: It reacts vigorously with burning agents for all fire classes.

questions.explanation: Halogenated Hydrocarbon is ozone depleted and global warning, but is a Clean agent, electrically non-conducting and has relatively low toxicity. [cite: 1881]

questions.question: What are the common hand-held fire extinguishers found on aircraft?

options.b: CO2, dry chemicals, and Halon.

questions.explanation: Hand-held extinguishers include CO2, Dry chemicals, and Halon. [cite: 1885]

questions.question: What is a 'squib' in a fire extinguishing system?

options.b: An explosive device in the discharge valve of a container, which drives a cutter to release the agent.
options.c: A manual valve for agent release.

questions.explanation: A squib is an explosive device in the discharge valve of a high-rate-discharge container of fire-extinguishing agent. The squib drives a cutter into the seal in the container to discharge the agent. [cite: 1892]

questions.subtopic: Gas Turbine Engine Fire Extinguishing System
questions.question: What type of fire extinguishing agent is typically used in High Rate of Discharge (HRD) systems fitted to most turbine aircraft?

options.b: Halon 1301.

questions.explanation: Fire extinguisher agent is Halon 1301. [cite: 1896]

questions.subtopic: Gas Turbine Engine Fire Extinguishing System
questions.question: What is the purpose of discharge indicators in fire extinguishing systems?

options.a: To provide a manual override for discharge.
options.b: To provide immediate visual evidence of container discharge.
options.c: To measure the pressure of the agent.

questions.explanation: Discharge Indicators provide immediate visual evidence of container discharge on fire extinguishing systems. [cite: 1898]

questions.question: What is one way aircraft electrical systems ensure reliability and redundancy?

options.a: By using a single large generator.
options.b: By having redundant sources of electrical power (e.g., generators, batteries, APU).

questions.explanation: Reliability and redundancy are ensured through redundant sources of electrical power (e.g., generators, batteries, APU). [cite: 52]

questions.question: During abnormal conditions, which type of loads are shed first in an aircraft electrical system?

options.b: Communication and navigation systems.
options.c: Non-essential loads (e.g., cabin lighting, galley power, entertainment).

questions.explanation: Non-essential loads (e.g., cabin lighting, galley power, entertainment) are shed first. [cite: 68]

questions.question: Which power source is described as a small gas turbine engine usually located in the tail section of the aircraft?

options.b: Auxiliary Power Unit (APU).

questions.explanation: The APU is a small gas turbine engine located usually in the tail section of the aircraft. [cite: 92]

questions.question: What are some internal sources of Electromagnetic Interference (EMI) in an aircraft?

options.b: Radios, radars, inverters, motors, and wiring bundles.
options.c: Airport radars and ground-based radio transmissions.

questions.explanation: Internal sources of EMI include radios, radars, inverters, motors, and wiring bundles. [cite: 205]

questions.question: Which of the following methods are used to control EMI/EMC in aircraft?

options.a: Using unshielded cables and random grounding.
options.b: Shielded cables, proper grounding, filtering circuits, and Faraday cages.
options.c: Increasing signal strength to overcome interference.

questions.explanation: Methods include Shielded cables, Proper grounding, Filtering circuits, Faraday cages, Twisted-pair wiring, Separation of systems, Bonding of structures, and Use of ferrites/chokes. [cite: 237, 238, 239, 240, 241, 242, 243, 244]

questions.question: What is the benefit of 'built-in diagnostics' in modern aircraft electrical systems?

options.b: They provide real-time fault detection and alerts directly to the cockpit or maintenance terminals.
options.c: They prevent any type of fault from occurring.

questions.explanation: Built-in Diagnostics provide fault codes, alerts, or system health reports directly to the cockpit or ground maintenance terminals. [cite: 272]

questions.question: What type of materials are important for electrical components to withstand high temperatures in aircraft?

options.b: Temperature-resistant materials (e.g., Teflon, Kapton insulation).

questions.explanation: Components must be made of temperature-resistant materials (e.g., Teflon, Kapton insulation). [cite: 316]

questions.question: How are electrical systems protected against moisture and rapid altitude changes?

options.a: By leaving them exposed to the elements.
options.b: Through sealed connectors, conformal coatings, and moisture barriers.
options.c: By operating only in dry conditions.

questions.explanation: Protection includes Sealed connectors, Conformal coatings, and Moisture barriers. [cite: 328, 329]

questions.subtopic: Purpose of the Aircraft Electrical Power System
questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the aircraft electrical power system?

options.b: To supply electrical power to all necessary equipment for safe and efficient operation, including avionics, lighting, hydraulic/fuel pump motors, environmental control, galley equipment, and safety systems.
options.c: To store fuel for the aircraft.

questions.explanation: The Aircraft Electrical Power System's purpose is to supply electrical power to: Avionics and flight instruments, Lighting systems (internal/external), Hydraulic and fuel pump motors, Environmental control systems, Galley equipment and passenger services, and Safety and emergency systems. [cite: 973, 974, 975]

questions.question: What is the main power source during flight for large aircraft?

options.b: Engine-Driven Generators, typically AC generators (alternators) producing 115V, 400Hz AC.

questions.explanation: Engine-Driven Generators are the main power source during flight, typically AC generators (alternators) producing 115V, 400Hz AC in large aircraft. [cite: 981, 982, 983]

questions.question: What is the function of a Transformer Rectifier Unit (TRU) in an aircraft electrical system?

options.a: Converts DC power to AC power.
options.b: Converts AC to DC for systems that need DC power.
options.c: Maintains constant output voltage from generators.

questions.explanation: A Transformer Rectifier Unit (TRU) converts AC to DC for systems that need DC power. [cite: 1009, 1025]

questions.question: What is the role of an 'Inverter' in an aircraft electrical system?

options.b: Converts DC power to AC power.

questions.explanation: An Inverter converts DC power to AC power. [cite: 1008, 1024]

questions.question: What is the function of 'Load Shedding Devices'?

options.a: To increase power to all systems.
options.b: To disconnect non-essential systems during low power situations.
options.c: To manually control electrical power flow.

questions.explanation: Load Shedding Devices disconnect non-essential systems during low power situations. [cite: 1015, 1031]

questions.question: Why are lead-acid batteries said to need 'water adjustment periodically'?

options.a: To increase the specific gravity of the electrolyte for improved performance.
options.b: Because gassing during overcharging causes water loss as H2O is converted to H2 and O2, which escapes through vent caps.
options.c: To prevent lead sulfate from forming hard crystals.

questions.explanation: Gassing causes water loss and therefore lead acid batteries need to have water adjustment periodically. This occurs during the recharging process as electricity flows through the electrolyte, H2O is converted to H2 and O2, and if overcharged, pressure from these gasses will cause relief caps to open and vent. [cite: 1371, 1374]

questions.question: What is the consequence of not immediately recharging a lead-acid battery after discharge?

options.a: The lead sulfate will reconvert into lead and sulfuric acid naturally.
options.b: The lead sulfate will begin to form hard crystals, which cannot be reconverted by a standard fixed voltage battery converter/charger.
options.c: The battery's capacity will temporarily increase.

questions.explanation: If a lead acid battery is not immediately recharged, the lead sulfate will begin to form hard crystals, which cannot be reconverted by a standard fixed voltage (13.6 volts) battery converter/charger. [cite: 1397]

questions.question: Why is Constant Current Charging (CCC) the preferred method for Ni-Cd batteries?

options.a: It is faster than constant voltage charging.
options.b: It ensures better cell balance and a total battery charge, and prevents the possibility of thermal runaway.
options.c: It reduces water loss during overcharging.

questions.explanation: Constant current charging of a Nickel-Cadmium batteries is recommended to ensure better cell balance and a total battery charge, as well as to prevent the possibility of thermal runaway. [cite: 1501]

questions.subtopic: Key Differences (DC Generator vs DC Alternator)
questions.question: What is the key difference in terms of the rotating and stationary parts between a DC Generator and a DC Alternator (AC with Rectifier)?

options.a: In a DC generator, the armature is stationary, and in a DC alternator, the field rotates.
options.b: In a DC generator, the armature rotates inside the stator; in a DC alternator, the field winding rotates inside the stator, inducing AC in the stationary armature.

questions.explanation: In a DC Generator, the armature rotates inside the stator, where electricity is induced in the rotating coil. In a DC Alternator (AC with Rectifier), the field winding rotates inside the stator, and its magnetic field rotates, inducing AC in the stationary armature. [cite: 1589]

questions.question: Why should grouping or bundling certain wires, such as electrically unprotected power wiring and wiring going to duplicated vital equipment, be avoided?

options.a: To make them easier to install.
options.b: To prevent interference and ensure continued operation of vital systems in case of a single point failure.
options.c: To reduce the overall weight of the aircraft.

questions.explanation: Grouping or bundling certain wires, such as electrically unprotected power wiring and wiring going to duplicated vital equipment, should be avoided. This is implicitly to prevent a single fault from affecting multiple critical systems. [cite: 1686]

questions.question: Why should wires and cable bundles never be installed crossing over each other?

options.a: It makes the wiring look untidy.
options.b: They may touch or rub against each other, causing chafing, which should never be allowed.

questions.explanation: Cables and cable bundles should never be installed crossing over each other. Otherwise, they may touch or rub against each other, causing chafing. Chafing should never be allowed. [cite: 1695, 1696]

questions.question: What is one of the main purposes of electrical grounding in an aircraft?

options.b: To protect aircraft and personnel against hazards from lightning discharge.

questions.explanation: Grounding of the aircraft is usually done to Protect aircraft and personnel against hazards from lightning discharge. [cite: 1710]

questions.question: Which of the following are included in EWIS (Electrical Wiring Interconnection System)?

options.b: Wires and cables, bus bars, termination points on electrical devices, connectors, electrical grounding and bonding devices, electrical splices, and protective materials for wires.

questions.explanation: EWIS includes: Wires and cables, Bus bars, The termination point on electrical devices, Connectors and Connector accessories, Electrical grounding and bonding devices and their associated connections, Electrical splices, Materials used to provide additional protection for wires (Shields or braids, Clamps, Cable ties devices, Labels or other means of identification). [cite: 1720, 1721]

questions.question: If you see only a White Light on another airplane at night, what does it indicate about its position?

options.a: The other airplane is coming at you.
options.b: The other airplane is flying away from you.
options.c: The other airplane is moving from right to left.

questions.explanation: If you see just a White Light, you know the other airplane is flying away from you. [cite: 1778]

questions.question: What is the difference in indication if you see both a Red and White Light versus a Green and White Light on another airplane?

options.a: Red and White means flying away; Green and White means coming towards you.
options.b: Red and White means moving from right to left (Port side); Green and White means moving from left to right (Starboard side).
options.c: Both indicate the airplane is stationary.

questions.explanation: If you see both a Red and White Light, you know the other airplane is moving from right to left as you see the Port side of the airplane. If you see both a Green and White Light, you know the other airplane is moving from left to right as you see the Starboard side of the airplane. [cite: 1779, 1780]

questions.question: What is the requirement for fire detection systems regarding false warnings and fire indication?

options.a: They should only provide warnings in extreme conditions.
options.b: No false warnings under any flight or ground condition, rapid indication, and accurate location of fire, along with accurate indication that a fire is out.
options.c: They only need to detect fire, not indicate if it's out.

questions.explanation: No false warnings under any flight or ground condition, Rapid indication and accurate location of fire, and Accurate indication that a fire is out. [cite: 1846]
